content.description: Although this climb is a result of short sighted behavior, it exists, and is one of the cleanest looking faces at Karen. Assembly Line ascends the south facing block in the center of Karen Rock. Climb one of two or three variations to reach the base of the block. Look for the drilled 2 finger pocket and decide to avoid it for 12a or pull on it for 11 a/b. A couple thin edges and a sloping top out get you up. If it weren't chipped it would have been 3 stars +.

Crux low. Crimps, slopers, and scoops get you up onto the slab. Move to the right under the roof and finish using the arete. Hoblet Roof (5.13a) pulls the roof and goes directly to the anchors.

Good route, employs a lot of different techniques.
content.protection: Set your toprope on the lower (about 2/3 of the way up) two bolt anchor accessed form the north trail on Karen Rock.
content.location:
Left of Lizard Head. The route goes up the light-colored "streak" of rock right of the large boulder that marks the start of the north trail for Karen Rock.

When finished, clean the anchor and walk off using the obvious trail.

content.description:
Urchin follows the

Standard Route

until it exits left into the chimney. At the top of the upper dihedral continue straight up ever steepening finger buckets until the surprise move to the "urchin". Find the two finger pocket with your left hand and mantel onto the slab.
content.protection: Stainless bolts above top out. Use long slings to extend over the chimney.
content.location:
Start

Standard Route

(look for the blocky holds).

content.description:
Not sure how this route didn't make it into the book.  If it has a name, please let me know.  Best gear route at Moonstone in my opinion.

Start right of the Standard Route (5.9), head up face to shallow dihedral/right-trending ramp.  Follow ramp to roof, traverse left out roof, finish on Standard Route/Karen Crack.
content.protection: Nuts/TCU's for bottom, cams to 2" for top.  3-bolt anchor at top of Karen Crack.

content.description: The Standard Route starts to the right of the prow on blocky face holds. It then continues up a small "dihedral" to a ledge. From there stem up the upper dihedral and exit through the chimney to the Karen Crack anchor
content.location: Right of the "prow" of Karen Rock. Look for the "blocky" holds.

content.description: Sky Hook is the classic dyno on Karen Rock. Balance up the first couple of steep slab moves and match on the diagonal letter box slot. From there, set your feet and launch for the sloping horn. Mantel onto the slab and continue on one of the other routes if top roping. If you are bouldering, down climb the start of Karen crack.
content.protection: Bolts and slings or stacked pads.
content.location: Sky Hook takes the prow just right of the Karen Crack start.

content.description: This arete just right of Assembly line is finally opened up for climbing with a bolted anchor. It was climbed many many years ago, but that tree anchor has rotted away. Climb the just left of the zigzag offwidth, then scramble up to the arÃªte. Like all of Moonstone, there are countless variations and eliminates, but the best here is to completely avoid the the dihedral features right of the arete. Climbing the dihedral is much much easier, but hasn't really been cleaned.
content.protection: Chordalette for the anchor. Two bolts. One obvious, one hidden.

content.description: Use any approach to reach the Sand Dollar Arete. Climb the LEFT side of the arete for it's entirety, A few techy sections and some nice sloper reach-arounds hidden on the other side of the arete. Drop the rope a foot left of the arete and it surprisingly does not climb contrived at all. Made possible by a new anchor.
content.protection: Two bolt anchor. Make sure to rig it to drop over the left face.

content.description: Nightmare begins by climbing the first half of Dream Theme. Where Dream Theme traverses right, after the large hueco, continue up and left through a blocky bulge to a horn of lighter colored rock. Make a difficult cross through to a series of large but sloping holds, make a couple of moves on these and then continue straight up to the anchor.
content.location: Right side of Karen Rock. Same start as Dream Theme.

content.description: Look for the "lizard head". Pull on the "head" to the crimp above. Fun line. This one is more of a summer/fall climb as this face is one of the few that seep in winter, due to the north facing direction.
content.protection: Bolts on the ledge above the route. Long slings.
content.location: Lizard head is located just to the left of the start of Karen Crack. A 2-3 finger protruding hold (the lizard head) marks this route. Set up your TR by going up the access path around the north side of Karen. About 2/3 of the way up, look for a path to a ledge on your right. This can be deadly slick if wet.

content.description: start on Look no more, as described in the guide, bust up to the sloper in the middle of the webbed face with your L hand and continue the route up and right making a throw to the Moonstoner arete.  Killer moves! hard.
content.location: climb starts as Look no more 5.13+ project but busts out right after you gain the bad sloper in the middle of the overhanging face.

content.description: Traverse the entire base of Karen Rock. Usually, done from left to right, so that you finish moving uphill.
content.location: Start as far left as possible on the base of Karen Rock. During Winter, you may have to start closer to the prow due to seepage.

content.description: This route tackles the roof above lizard head.  It may seem a bit confusing at first, but after climbing lizard head, walk up the slab up and left. once you reach the L hand sidepull-sloper under the roof, climb directly out the center of the roof on small crimps and slopers.  Great challenge on immaculate crimpers and slopers.  Boulder problem on a rope.  about v6-v7.
content.location: above "lizard head" (10d) and "way hard rock climbing betty", (10d).

content.description: Route starts up huecos left of prow, then up finger crack with chimney finish. Classic Moonstone lead. Karen rock also has many toprope variations and a good traverse along the base.
content.protection: Medium cams in pockets at start, finger size cams/nuts, run out the short chimney. Bolt anchor, bring long slings for toproping.
content.location: Karen rock is the largest formation at Moonstone beach. Karen crack is obvious line left of the prow. Walk off.

content.description: Just after the crux of Assembly Line, instead of just finishing left on that huge jug, head straight right to Sand Dollar Arete Left, using a large undercling, large foot, and a poor pinch. Great climb!
content.protection: 2 bolts, long chord. Use one bolt from Assembly Line and one from the Sand Dollar Arete and makeÂ sure to rig the anchor equidistant between the two sets of anchors
content.location: Drop your rope halfway between Assembly Line and Sand Dollar Arete. Rigging it too far right risks a bad swing. Right in the middle is safe.

content.description:
The route starts on the face between Urchin and Assembly Line. Climb straight up to the roof. It would be wise to rest under the roof because the crux is directly above and requires a lot of strength and endurance.

Grab the horn sticking out to the left, and the sideways jug above that before working your way left to a 3 finger pocket and a crimp. Smear your way up and dino to a good jug up and to the left. From there, work your way back to the right across the face and up over the ledge to top out.

The dino area leading up to the dino and the dino itself are the are the crux of the route.
content.protection: There is a 3 point anchor at the top of the rock. Take the path to the right up to the top and set your anchor. There are currently no bolts for leading. This is top-rope only.
content.location: This is at Karen Rock. Take a right out of the parking lot. It's the first massive face that you see. The start is between Urchin and Assembly Line, but you can start at Urchin as the start is easier. The descent is a standard lower from top rope belay.

content.description: Dream Theme is one of the most prominent lines on Karen Rock. Start by underclinging the left leaning finger crack, reach right to the rounded side pull, put your right foot high and reach left to a undercling/sidepull. Step up and grab the "six pack handle" with your right hand. Reach through with your left hand to the first right facing edge. Grab the next edge with your right hand. Pull through to the giant hueco and the "egg". Traverse right under the roof and up the face to the anchors.
content.location: Dream Theme is located on the center of the right-side face of Karen Rock.

content.description: Start by balancing up onto the slab, then use small "pockets" to crimps (first crux). From there head straight up to the ramp layback (second crux) to the ledge. A heel hook left or right is handy for the final move before manteling onto the ledge.
content.location: Center face is located just right of Skyhook.
